close_symbols: UT_StubTableEntry_t (full struct/union definition, including Data.Buff.TotalSize, Data.Buff.Position, Data.Buff.BasePtr and their types)
UT_GetStubEntry (prototype and specification/contract; how/when it returns NULL or a valid pointer and pointer lifetime/ownership)
UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER (definition / value used when calling UT_GetStubEntry)
UT_SetDataBuffer (prototype and spec; how it initializes Data.Buff fields and any invariants it establishes)
UT_GetDataBuffer (prototype/spec; how it reads or validates Data.Buff fields)
UT_ClearStubEntry (prototype and behavior; what it does to Data.Buff.BasePtr/Position/TotalSize)
UT_Hook_GetArgPtr (prototype and contract; how callers obtain LocalBuffer and whether it can be NULL or have limited size)
size_t typedef (definition / width and unsignedness assumptions)
explanation:
For a MISRA C analysis of memcpy usage in UT_Stub_CopyToLocal you must be able to prove the three pointer/length relationships: (1) the source pointer (&StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr[Position]) is valid for ActualCopy bytes, (2) the destination pointer (LocalBuffer) is valid for ActualCopy bytes, and (3) ActualCopy is computed without underflow/wraparound. The listed symbols are required for that proof: 

- UT_StubTableEntry_t: gives the exact types and sizes of TotalSize, Position and the element type of BasePtr so you can reason about arithmetic (TotalSize - Position), pointer arithmetic (&BasePtr[Position]), and the actual buffer length that BasePtr points to. Without the struct you cannot determine bounds or signed/unsigned semantics.

- UT_GetStubEntry: the function returns the StubPtr used here. Its specification/contract is needed to know whether the returned pointer is valid, whether it can alias other memory, and how long it remains valid (lifetime), which affects whether the BasePtr and TotalSize/Position are trustworthy.

- UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER: documents the meaning of the lookup and ensures UT_GetStubEntry is being used for the correct stub type; needed to know that Data.Buff fields are present and initialized for this entry type.

- UT_SetDataBuffer and UT_GetDataBuffer: these functions (or their specs) show how the buffer is created/initialized and what invariants they establish (for example, that Position <= TotalSize and that BasePtr points to an array of length TotalSize). Those invariants are essential to prove TotalSize - Position cannot underflow and that the source buffer is large enough.

- UT_ClearStubEntry: needed to know how clearing affects BasePtr/TotalSize/Position and whether there are race/ownership issues that could make BasePtr invalid at the time of memcpy (in case of concurrent or reentrant behavior). Also documents any postconditions used elsewhere.

- UT_Hook_GetArgPtr: many callers obtain LocalBuffer via this helper before calling UT_Stub_CopyToLocal. Its contract tells you whether LocalBuffer can be NULL, what its allocated size guarantees (if any), and whether the caller ensures MaxSize matches the actual size. This is necessary to prove the destination buffer is large enough for ActualCopy bytes.

- memcpy declaration: the exact prototype and semantics (undefined behavior when source/destination overlap or pointers invalid) are required to apply the MISRA rule and to state what constitutes a violation.

- size_t typedef: establishes unsignedness and width to reason about the subtraction TotalSize - Position, comparisons with MaxSize, and potential underflow/wraparound.

Providing these symbols (definitions and specifications/contracts) lets the next analyst determine whether: (a) Position <= TotalSize always holds so the subtraction cannot underflow; (b) BasePtr points to at least TotalSize bytes so &BasePtr[Position]..+ActualCopy-1 are valid; and (c) LocalBuffer points to at least MaxSize (or at least ActualCopy) bytes so memcpy cannot write out of bounds. Without these symbols the bounds-safety of the memcpy call cannot be established.
